We investigate the effect of continuous-wave laser irradiation on the cavity evolution behind a sphere in water entry. By tuning the irradiation time, the surface temperature (Ts) of the sphere bef...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: We investigate the effect of continuous-wave laser irradiation on the cavity evolution behind a sphere in water entry. By tuning the irradiation time, the surface temperature (Ts) of the sphere before the impact varies in 105–355 °C. We change the radius and impact velocity of the sphere, by which both the shallow and deep seals are considered. Compared to the reference case (the sphere was roughened to have a cavity initially), we find that the cavity expands or shrinks depending on Ts. Overall, for all cases, the cavity bubble expands to the maximum size and shrinks steeply with increasing Ts. At higher Ts, the cavity is destroyed significantly, even smaller than the reference case. However, the detailed interaction between the cavity and laser-induced cavitation bubbles is quite different. In a shallow-seal case, nucleate boiling occurs on the sphere surface and vapor bubbles merge into the cavity, resulting in the expansion of the cavity. At a highly subcooled condition, on the other hand, the vapor bubble collapses into microbubbles as soon as it contacts water, resulting in the cavity reduction. As the impact speed increases (for a deep-seal condition), the flux of entrained air becomes dominant and the stage of cavity expansion is quite narrow. As Ts increases, the heated cavity collapses into microbubbles and almost 90% is destroyed. Finally, we investigate the effects of modified cavity on hydrodynamic forces on the sphere. While the temporal variation of hydrodynamic forces is complex, the drag reduction over 40% is achieved.
meta.name: citation_abstract

div.div:
We investigate the effect of continuous-wave laser irradiation on the cavity evolution behind a sphere in water entry. By tuning the irradiation time, the surface temperature (
T
s
) of the sphere before the impact varies in 105–355 °C. We change the radius and impact velocity of the sphere, by which both the shallow and deep seals are considered. Compared to the reference case (the sphere was roughened to have a cavity initially), we find that the cavity expands or shrinks depending on
T
s
. Overall, for all cases, the cavity bubble expands to the maximum size and shrinks steeply with increasing
T
s
. At higher
T
s
, the cavity is destroyed significantly, even smaller than the reference case. However, the detailed interaction between the cavity and laser-induced cavitation bubbles is quite different. In a shallow-seal case, nucleate boiling occurs on the sphere surface and vapor bubbles merge into the cavity, resulting in the expansion of the cavity. At a highly subcooled condition, on the other hand, the vapor bubble collapses into microbubbles as soon as it contacts water, resulting in the cavity reduction. As the impact speed increases (for a deep-seal condition), the flux of entrained air becomes dominant and the stage of cavity expansion is quite narrow. As
T
s
increases, the heated cavity collapses into microbubbles and almost 90% is destroyed. Finally, we investigate the effects of modified cavity on hydrodynamic forces on the sphere. While the temporal variation of hydrodynamic forces is complex, the drag reduction over 40% is achieved.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

From a traditional point of view, the cavitation bubble is regarded as being unfavorable (it is still critical in many areas) due to its consequences such as mechanical damage, pressure drop, and unpredictable disturbance to the system (
Plesset, 1949
29. Plesset, M. S., “
The dynamics of cavitation bubbles
,” J. Appl. Mech.
16
, 277–
282
(1949).
;
Naudé and Ellis, 1961
24. Naudé, C. F. and Ellis, A. T., “
On the mechanism of cavitation damage nonhemispherical cavities collapsing in contact with a solid boundary
,” J. Basic Eng.
83
, 648–
656
(1961).
https://doi.org/10.1115/1.3662286
;
Brennen, 1995
6. Brennen, C. E.,
Cavitation and Bubble Dynamics
(
Oxford University Press
, 1995).
; and
Philipp and Lauterborn, 1998
27. Philipp, A. and Lauterborn, W., “
Cavitation erosion by single laser-produced bubbless
,” J. Fluid Mech.
361
, 75–
116
(1998).
https://doi.org/10.1017/s0022112098008738
). If it is possible to control the formation and evolution of the bubble, however, we may find a way to utilize it in favorable directions. As one of the methods to achieve it, focusing of a pulsed or continuous-wave (CW) laser beam on to a tiny spot in a liquid or on a metallic surface has been investigated quite seriously (
Tomita and Shima, 1990
34. Tomita, T. and Shima, A., “
High-speed photographic observations of laser-induced cavitation bubbles in water
,” Acustica
71
, 161–
171
(1990).
;
Baffou
et al.
, 2014
3. Baffou, G., Polleux, J., Rigneault, H., and Monneret, S., “
Super-heating and micro-bubble generation around plasmonic nanoparticles under cw illumination
,” J. Phys. Chem. C
118
, 4890–
4898
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jp411519k
; and
Kim
et al.
,2019
17. Kim, N., Park, H., and Do, H., “
Evolution of cavitation bubble in tap water by continuous-wave laser focused on a metallic surface
,” Langmuir
35
, 3308–
3318
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.8b04083
), which is known to have an advantage in terms of controllability and fast response (
Zheng
et al.
, 2012
45. Zheng, Y. J., Wang, Y., Liu, H., Zhu, C., Wang, S. M., Cao, J. X., and Zhu, S. N., “
Size control of vapor bubbles on a silver film by a tuned CW laser
,” AIP Adv.
2
, 022155 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4730929
;
Wang
et al.
, 2017
40. Wang, Y., Zaytsev, M. E., The, H. L., Eijkel, J. C. T., Zandvliet, H. J. W., Zhang, X., and Lohse, D., “
Vapor and gas-bubble growth dynamics around laser-irradiated, water-immersed plasmonic nanoparticles
,” ACS Nano
11
, 2045–
2051
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.6b08229
). Compared to other light (photon) sources, the laser has a superior collimated property as well.

The cavitation bubble induced by a pulsed laser is characterized by the explosive growth-collapse dynamics and subsequent forcing (momentum transport) to the surroundings. As a high laser energy is absorbed by the liquid immediately after emission, the interaction between the photons and targeted matter induces a plasma within ∼1
μ
s and a cavitation bubble [maximum radius of
O
(1) mm] grows explosively (
Lam
et al.
, 2016
18. Lam, J., Lombard, J., Dujardin, C., Ledoux, G., Merabia, S., and Amans, D., “
Dynamical study of bubble expansion following laser ablation in liquids
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
108
, 074104 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4942389
). This bubble collapses within a short time [
O
(10
3
)
μ
s], while releasing a jet and shock wave (
Oweis
et al.
, 2004
25. Oweis, G. F., Choi, J., and Ceccio, S. L., “
Dynamics and noise emission of laser induced cavitation bubbles in a vortical flow field
,” J. Acoust. Soc. Am.
115
, 1049–
1058
(2004).
https://doi.org/10.1121/1.1646402
).
Akhatov
et al.
(2002)
1. Akhatov, I., Vakhitova, N., Topolnikov, A., Zakirov, K., Wolfrum, B., Kurz, T., Lindau, O., Mettin, R., and Lauterborn, W., “
Dynamics of laser-induced cavitation bubbles
,” Exp. Therm. Fluid Sci.
26
, 731–
737
(2002).
https://doi.org/10.1016/s0894-1777(02)00182-6
numerically showed that condensation occurs when the bubble expands to the maximum size, resulting in the loss of a mass up to 5% of the initial value. This causes the increase in pressure and temperature inside the bubble to approximately 10
5
bar and 10
4
K, respectively. On the other hand, the generation of bubbles with a CW laser has been found to be more useful in maintaining the bubble for a longer duration, especially on a solid surface, despite its lower energy density compared to the pulsed laser. By focusing a 532 nm CW laser on a silver-coated surface,
Zheng
et al.
(2012)
45. Zheng, Y. J., Wang, Y., Liu, H., Zhu, C., Wang, S. M., Cao, J. X., and Zhu, S. N., “
Size control of vapor bubbles on a silver film by a tuned CW laser
,” AIP Adv.
2
, 022155 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4730929
found that the bubble expands only when the laser energy is higher than the dissipated energy, otherwise it contracts.
Baffou
et al.
(2014)
3. Baffou, G., Polleux, J., Rigneault, H., and Monneret, S., “
Super-heating and micro-bubble generation around plasmonic nanoparticles under cw illumination
,” J. Phys. Chem. C
118
, 4890–
4898
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jp411519k
created microbubbles by heating gold nanoparticles on a glass surface and showed that the bubble lifetime [up to
O
(10
2
) seconds] is proportional to its volume. On the other hand,
Wang
et al.
(2017)
40. Wang, Y., Zaytsev, M. E., The, H. L., Eijkel, J. C. T., Zandvliet, H. J. W., Zhang, X., and Lohse, D., “
Vapor and gas-bubble growth dynamics around laser-irradiated, water-immersed plasmonic nanoparticles
,” ACS Nano
11
, 2045–
2051
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.6b08229
tried to explain the mechanism of bubble growth as a function of irradiation time while considering two types of the liquids as air-equilibrated and degassed water. The bubble growth was governed by the evaporation of water at an early stage, but the later stage was mostly driven by the influx of gas dissolved in the water. Very recently,
Kim
et al.
(2019)
17. Kim, N., Park, H., and Do, H., “
Evolution of cavitation bubble in tap water by continuous-wave laser focused on a metallic surface
,” Langmuir
35
, 3308–
3318
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.8b04083
examined the evolution of a millimeter-size bubble induced by a CW laser focused on a metallic surface in various liquids and suggested different driving forces that govern the bubble growth and collapse depending on the irradiation time and laser energy. With a lower laser energy, the bubbles are generated mostly due to the phase change (vaporization or condensation) of water; however, the vaporization of the gas dissolved in water contributes more to the bubble growth as the laser energy increases.

Thus far, the generation of the cavitation bubbles using a focused laser has been applied to the field of microfluidics (
Zhang
et al.
, 2011
42. Zhang, K., Jian, A., Zhang, X., Want, Y., Li, Z., and Tam, H., “
Laser-induced thermal bubbles for microfluidic applications
,” Lab Chip
11
, 1389–
1395
(2011).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c0lc00520g
), droplet generation (
Park
et al.
, 2011
26. Park, S., Wu, T., Chen, Y., Teitell, M., and Chiou, P., “
High-speed droplet generation on demand driven by pulse laser-induced cavitation
,” Lab Chip
11
, 1010–
1012
(2011).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c0lc00555j
), surface cleaning (
Song
et al.
, 2004
32. Song, W. D., Hong, M. H., Lukyanchuk, B., and Chong, T. C., “
Laser-induced cavitation bubbles for cleaning of solid surfaces
,” J. Appl. Phys.
95
, 2952–
2956
(2004).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1650531
), and so on, mostly owing to the very fast (less than a second) generation/collapse of the submillimeter sized bubble. According to
Zhang
et al.
(2011)
42. Zhang, K., Jian, A., Zhang, X., Want, Y., Li, Z., and Tam, H., “
Laser-induced thermal bubbles for microfluidic applications
,” Lab Chip
11
, 1389–
1395
(2011).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c0lc00520g
, for example, bubbles can be used as a micropump or microvalve in microchannels, and
Zhao
et al.
(2014)
43. Zhao, C., Xie, Y., Mao, Z., Zhao, Y., Rufo, J., Yang, S., Guo, F., Mai, J. D., and Huang, T. J., “
Theory and experiment on particle trapping and manipulation via optothermally generated bubbles
,” Lab Chip
14
, 384–
391
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c3lc50748c
utilized bubbles to collect and transport particles selectively. Even though the growth rate of the CW laser-induced bubble is lower than that of a pulsed laser, the former can be more practical in industrial applications because its size is controllable. Furthermore, if it is possible to control the evolution of a millimeter sized bubble for a longer duration (
Kim
et al.
, 2019
17. Kim, N., Park, H., and Do, H., “
Evolution of cavitation bubble in tap water by continuous-wave laser focused on a metallic surface
,” Langmuir
35
, 3308–
3318
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.8b04083
), it is possible to come up with much wider potential applications. One of the possibilities that we want to test in this work is to control the existing cavity bubble using the laser-induced bubbles. While this application is quite attractive considering its potential impacts (e.g., control of the cavitation bubble in turbomachinery), to the best of our knowledge, this idea has not been tested and/or investigated seriously and thus basic research studies are required. On the other hand, it is well known that a cavity bubble (called low-speed cavity) forms behind a falling body (e.g., sphere) when the body impacts and deforms the interface between the air and liquid (
Duez
et al.
, 2007
10. Duez, C., Vbert, C., Clanet, C., and Bocquet, L., “
Making a splash with water repellency
,” Nat. Phys.
3
, 180–
183
(2007).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nphys545
;
Aristoff and Bush, 2009
2. Aristoff, J. M. and Bush, J. W. M., “
Water entry of small hydrophobic spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
619
, 45–
78
(2009).
https://doi.org/10.1017/s0022112008004382
;
Truscott
et al.
, 2014
35. Truscott, T. T., Epps, B. P., and Belden, J., “
Water entry of projectiles
,” Annu. Rev. Fluid Mech.
46
, 355–
378
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-fluid-011212-140753
;
Mansoor
et al.
, 2017
22. Mansoor, M. M., Vakarelski, I. U., Marston, J. O., Truscott, T. T., and Thoroddsen, S. T., “
Stable-streamlined and helical cavities following the impact of Leidenfrost spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
823
, 716–
754
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2017.337
;
Kim and Park, 2019
16. Kim, N. and Park, H., “
Water entry of rounded cylindrical bodies with different aspect ratios and surface conditions
,” J. Fluid Mech.
863
, 757–
788
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2018.1026
; and
Wang
et al.
, 2019
39. Wang, J., Faltinsen, O. M., and Lugni, C., “
Unsteady hydrodynamic forces of solid objects vertically entering the water surface
,” Phys. Fluids
31
, 027101 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5057744
). Since the characteristic time scale [≤
O
(10
2
) ns] for the evolution of vapor nanobubbles with a CW laser (
Hou
et al.
, 2015
12. Hou, L., Yorulmaz, M., Verhart, N. R., and Orrit, M., “
Explosive formation and dynamics of vapor nanobubbles around a continuously heated gold nanosphere
,” New J. Phys.
17
, 013050 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1367-2630/17/1/013050
) is smaller than the physical time scale [
t
o
=
D
o
/
U
o
∼
O
(10
3
)
μ
s, where
D
o
and
U
o
are the sphere diameter and impact velocity, respectively] of a low-speed cavity bubble in the water entry problem, we think this is a good problem to test and understand the possible mechanism of cavity control with laser-induced bubbles. Also, it is allowed to test in a more controllable experimental environment. The water entry of a solid body is closely related to the ocean engineering and military applications such as a ship slamming, stability of offshore structures, oceanographic measurement devices, and launching of ballistics (
Kim and Park, 2019
16. Kim, N. and Park, H., “
Water entry of rounded cylindrical bodies with different aspect ratios and surface conditions
,” J. Fluid Mech.
863
, 757–
788
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2018.1026
). For example, the mechanical bathythermograph (MBT), a torpedo-shaped device containing a sensor and a transducer to detect changes in water temperature with respect to depth, is launched at 2–30 m above the sea surface. In this case, the cavity attached to the device affects the drag force on it and thus its control is quite important (
Shi
et al.
, 2019
31. Shi, Y., Wang, G., and Pan, G., “
Experimental study on cavity dynamics of projectile water entry with different physical parameters
,” Phys. Fluids
31
, 067103 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5096588
).

Previously, it was shown that the dynamics of a cavity bubble strongly affects the hydrodynamics of a sinking body. For example, a Worthington jet generated after the cavity pinch-off transfers momentum to the descending body, so it can descend faster than the one without a cavity (
Truscott
et al.
, 2012
36. Truscott, T. T., Epps, B. P., and Techet, A. H., “
Unsteady forces on spheres during free-surface water entry
,” J. Fluid Mech.
704
, 173–
210
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2012.232
). Also, the cavity bubble disturbs the vortex shedding in the wake, which is the main source of the unsteady drag force on a sinking body. The formation of a low-speed cavity depends on the impact velocity, the static contact angle and roughness of the body surface, and so on. When the static contact angle (
θ
s
) of a surface is less than 90°, i.e., it is hydrophilic, the liquid film induced from the impact can move along the solid surface with a high capillary force, and a higher momentum is required to separate the liquid film from the solid surface. Thus, the cavity is formed at a higher impact velocity when
θ
s
< 90° (
Duez
et al.
, 2007
10. Duez, C., Vbert, C., Clanet, C., and Bocquet, L., “
Making a splash with water repellency
,” Nat. Phys.
3
, 180–
183
(2007).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nphys545
). On the other hand, the surface roughness disturbs the movement of the liquid film and induces the film to separate earlier from the surface to create a splash and cavity, by which the critical velocity for cavity formation is reduced (
Zhao
et al.
, 2014
44. Zhao, M., Chen, X., and Wang, Q., “
Wetting failure of hydrophilic surfaces promoted by surface roughness
,” Sci. Rep.
4
, 5376 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/srep05376
). Another condition to form a cavity bubble is to heat up the body surface (
Zvirin
et al.
, 1990
46. Zvirin, Y., Hewitt, G. R., and Kenning, D. B. R., “
Boiling on free-falling spheres: Drag and heat transfer coefficients
,” Exp. Heat Transfer
3
, 185–
214
(1990).
https://doi.org/10.1080/08916159008946386
;
Marston
et al.
, 2012
23. Marston, J. O., Vakarelski, I. U., and Thoroddsen, S. T., “
Cavity formation by the impact of Leidenfrost spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
699
, 465–
488
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2012.124
;
Mansoor
et al.
, 2017
22. Mansoor, M. M., Vakarelski, I. U., Marston, J. O., Truscott, T. T., and Thoroddsen, S. T., “
Stable-streamlined and helical cavities following the impact of Leidenfrost spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
823
, 716–
754
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2017.337
; and
Li
et al.
, 2018
19. Li, J. C., Wei, Y. J., Wang, C., and Xia, W. X., “
Cavity formation during water entry of heated spheres
,” Chin. Phys. B
27
, 094703 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1674-1056/27/9/094703
). Known as the Leidenfrost effect, when the sphere is heated above the Leidenfrost temperature [for example, ∼300 °C in the water of 85 °C for superhydrophobic surfaces (
Vakarelski
et al.
, 2014
37. Vakarelski, I. U., Chan, D. Y., and Thoroddsen, S. T., “
Leidenfrost vapour layer moderation of the drag crisis and trajectories of superhydrophobic and hydrophilic spheres falling in water
,” Soft Matter
10
, 5662–
5668
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c4sm00368c
)], nucleate boiling occurs on the surface near the equator of a sphere, and a vapor layer is produced until the sphere is fully encapsulated by the gas (
Marston
et al.
, 2012
23. Marston, J. O., Vakarelski, I. U., and Thoroddsen, S. T., “
Cavity formation by the impact of Leidenfrost spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
699
, 465–
488
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2012.124
). According to
Mansoor
et al.
(2017)
22. Mansoor, M. M., Vakarelski, I. U., Marston, J. O., Truscott, T. T., and Thoroddsen, S. T., “
Stable-streamlined and helical cavities following the impact of Leidenfrost spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
823
, 716–
754
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2017.337
, the Leidenfrost sphere creates an unstable, stable, or helical cavity depending on the impact conditions. When the cavity is maintained to be a stable like streamlined shape, the sphere descends steadily and experiences a lower drag compared to a helical cavity. Although the drag coefficient of the sphere with a helical cavity increases with time, it has a significantly smaller value in the initial stage of sinking compared to the sphere with a typical wake structure of the Karman vortex street (i.e., the reference case is without cavity). However, this approach is to create the cavity bubble initially with the heating, and thus it is different from the control of the existing cavity bubble with laser-induced bubbles.

Therefore, in this study, we experimentally investigate the control of the cavity bubble behind a falling metallic sphere in water entry, by focusing a CW laser on the frontal surface of the sphere. While changing the time duration of laser focusing, i.e., the surface temperature at the impact, we investigate the interaction between the cavity bubble formed by the deformation of the air-water interface and laser-induced cavitation bubbles. We also change the size of the sphere and impacting speed to consider different types of cavity dynamics [i.e., shallow and deep seals (
Truscott
et al.
, 2014
35. Truscott, T. T., Epps, B. P., and Belden, J., “
Water entry of projectiles
,” Annu. Rev. Fluid Mech.
46
, 355–

Using a high-speed shadowgraphy, we measure the change in the size of the cavity bubble and the trajectory of the sphere, which are used to calculate the hydrodynamic forces acting on the sphere. Finally, we suggest possible mechanisms of the cavity bubble modification in relation to the condition of laser-induced bubbles (i.e., surface temperature). We believe that the present results will be quite useful to extend the possible areas for which the laser-induced cavitation bubbles are applied.
II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP AND PROCEDURE

It was suggested that the water film rising on the rough surface separates earlier and the air can enter between the water film and the rough surface, resulting in the cavity formation, because the rising water film cannot penetrate into the roughness (
Zhao
et al.
2014

https://doi.org/10.1038/srep05376
;
Kim and Park, 2019

,” J. Fluid Mech.
863
, 757–
788
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2018.1026
). To make a rough sphere, we use two methods. For most of the cases (except one case explained below), we corroded the sphere surface by putting it into a 20 ml of etching solution (FeCl
3
+ HCl solution, HCl concentration is 20%) in an Erlenmeyer flask with a magnet stirrer; the sphere surface was etched at 1500 rpm for 25 min. With this condition, we get a roughness with
R
t
= 8.3 ± 1.1
μ
m [
Fig. 1(b)
]. Here, the maximum height of surface roughness (
R
t
), defined as the maximum distance between the valley and the peak, is measured using a 3D surface profiler (
μ
surf, NanoFocus). For the case of
R
○
= 2 mm and
U
○
= 1.5 m/s, we roughen the sphere surface using sandpaper (grit number 150) to get a roughness size, which is sufficiently large to achieve a shallow-seal condition (due to larger
R
○
, the etching-based method was not able to achieve this). With this method,
R
t
is measured to be 11.4 ± 0.4
μ
m, and the corresponding Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) image is shown in
Fig. 1(c)
. All the spheres were cleaned with DI (de-ionized) water after it was roughened and then dried for more than 24 h. With a rough sphere, it is possible to get a well-defined cavity, increase the repeatability of experiments, and investigate how the incident laser controls the cavity bubble.

To control the cavity by focusing the CW laser on the falling sphere, we use a 532 nm wavelength CW laser (RayPower 5000, Dantec Dynamics). The maximum power in front of the sphere is approximately 4.6 W, which was measured using a power meter (PM100D, Thorlabs) with a thermal sensor (S425C, Thorlabs). To illuminate the large area of the sphere (to avoid having a locally isolated influence on the sphere surface), we use no optics to focus the laser beam further, and thus the resulting beam has a diameter of about 4 mm. The corresponding energy density illuminated on the half of the sphere surface is 1.8 × 10
5
W/cm
2
. To control the irradiation time, two laser line mirrors (a diameter of 25 mm with an incident angle of 45°) are placed in front of the laser and the first mirror is connected to the servomotor [
Fig. 1(a)
]. Initially, the laser beam is sent to a beam dump by the first mirror. When the servomotor is operated, the first mirror moves and the laser beam can reach the sphere through the second mirror. After the laser is irradiated for the designated time (i.e., to control the surface temperature of the sphere), the vacuum pump is turned off to drop the sphere. We irradiate the laser continuously onto the sphere until it reaches the bottom of the tank. The entire process of laser irradiation is controlled through Arduino. In this study, the laser irradiation time indicates the time duration during which the laser is focused, while it is held by the vacuum pump, and it is controlled from 0 (reference case) to 40 s. We install two iris diaphragms to align the reflected laser vertically. First, we set the minimum aperture of 1.6 mm and control the laser light to pass through both centers of two iris diaphragms and confirm that it is directed to the sphere stagnation point vertically. Then, we open it to the maximum aperture of 33 mm, so it does not disturb the falling motion of a sphere. We also use a new sphere for each measurement because the irradiation of a CW laser onto a metallic surface would cause mechanical damages (ablations) (
Kim
et al.
, 2019
17. Kim, N., Park, H., and Do, H., “
Evolution of cavitation bubble in tap water by continuous-wave laser focused on a metallic surface
,” Langmuir
35
, 3308–
3318
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.8b04083
).
B. High-speed shadowgraph imaging

The variation of the cavity bubble is visually measured using a high-speed camera (SpeedSense M310, Dantec Dynamics) at the rate of 5000 fps (1280 × 400 pixels). The plane LED with a wavelength of 675 nm is placed on the opposite side of camera to obtain the shadow images of a sphere and a cavity bubble. We use different lenses depending on the region of interest; 50 mm and 100 mm macrolenses (Samyang) are used to measure the trajectory and cavity volume of the sphere, and magnified images are obtained with a 180 mm macrolens (Sigma) for detailed investigations. In all the cases, the lenses are fitted with an extension tube (12 mm, 20 mm, or 36 mm depending on the situation) and an orange filter (a cutoff wavelength of 570 nm) to reduce image noise caused by the laser reflections. With this setup, the spatial resolution is in the range 0.035
D
○
–0.042
D
○
and the temporal resolution is 0.075

–0.323
t
○
, where

○

D
○
/

○
.

C. Temperature measurement of the sphere surface

A midwave infrared (MWIR) camera is used to measure the instantaneous temperature of the falling sphere, at a frame rate of 125 Hz and a spatial resolution of 640 × 512 pixels. To measure the temperature of an object with an infrared camera, it is necessary to determine the emissivity (

s

These techniques provide a relatively accurate measurement, but they are not available currently. Thus, the emissivity is measured indirectly, using an MWIR camera (A6753SC, FLIR) with a superior temperature resolution of 0.02 °C. There was a sufficient heat transfer over the entire sphere, and the difference in temperature measured by both thermocouples is within 2 °C. The front of the sphere observed by the camera is set to be the region of interest (ROI). The emissivity is obtained from Eq.

FIG. 2.
(a) Experimental setup to measure the emissivity of roughened spheres. (b) Variation of emissivity of the spheres with the surface temperature. (c) Comparison of surface temperature variation according to the laser irradiation time, from microthermocouple and MWIR camera measurements.

After we have confirmed our method to measure the emissivity, we applied it to the water entry facility, explained in Sec.
II A
. The IR cameras obtain the temperature using the detector electrical signal and object emissivity to get the radiance [Eq.
(3)
], which is used to calculate the temperature. However, as shown in
Fig. 2(b)
, the emissivity varies with the temperature. Thus, we planned the procedure outlined below. First, the sphere is exposed to the laser beam, while two microthermocouples are attached on both sides. This provides a relatively accurate measurement of temperature increase with time. Two thermocouples have a temperature deviation smaller than 2 °C, as confirmed above. Using the temperature (from the thermocouples), we obtain the emissivity value from the calibrated data. Together with the electrical signals from the MWIR camera, which is located in front of the sphere, the temperature map can be obtained. The area-averaged temperature from the IR camera is within 10 °C from that measured by the thermocouples, as shown in
Fig. 2(c)
. Next, we remove the thermocouples from the sphere and perform the free fall of the sphere into the water tank. The free-fall distance is less than 600 mm, which corresponds to a time duration of less than 1 s. The temperature change during this period was small, within a few degrees. Thus, the same emissivity value is used to obtain the instantaneous temperature of the sphere right before it enters the water. On the other hand, it is measured that the difference between the maximum temperature and the minimum temperature along the horizontal and vertical directions (on the sphere surface) is about 7 °C and 12 °C when the area-averaged temperature is 200 °C. When the surface temperature increases to 250 °C and 300 °C, the deviation is about 10 °C/14 °C and 10 °C/12 °C along each direction, respectively. Thus, the level of nonuniformity is less than 6% of the measured temperature, and we think this amount of difference would not significantly affect the measured phenomena. Considering this local difference, we use the area-averaged temperature value, which is calculated by dividing the integration of temperature on the sphere with its cross-sectional area. This is defined as the surface temperature,
T
s
. In the present study, the sphere surface temperature varies in 105–355 °C.

It is now clear that the cavity behind a falling sphere in water entry can be controlled dramatically depending on the surface temperature at the instant of impact. Based on the highly subcooled condition (water at room temperature and the sphere surface at about 105–355 °C), the interaction between the cavity bubble and laser-induced cavitation bubbles (due to the phase change) is closely related to these phenomena. R

].

In summary, the surface tension contributes dominantly in the case of controlling the cavity behind a smaller sphere in the shallow-seal regime, whether the cavity bubble grows or shrinks owing to the laser irradiation. This results in the significant drag reduction caused by the attached cavity. When the sphere size increases, the added mass and buoyancy forces become comparable to the surface tension force, which results in more complex variation in a drag. Still, the drag reduction is achieved with the control. When the reference case is the deep seal, the cavity volume (i.e., added mass and buoyancy forces) variation determines the drag force. When the temperature of sphere increases much higher for a larger sphere, in particular, the cavity is destroyed significantly and the drag increases due to the reduced buoyancy force.
V. CONCLUDING REMARKS
Section:

This study carried out experiments on how the cavity behind the sphere in water entry changes according to the surface temperature (raised by the CW laser irradiation) and impact velocity. The temporal evolution of the cavity bubble is measured visually with a high-speed camera, and the unsteady surface temperature is also measured with a MWIR camera. For the considered ranges of parameters, the cavity bubble is not formed behind a stainless steel sphere; thus, we intentionally roughened the surface to induce a cavity bubble, which is regarded as a reference case. Whether the initial cavity bubble is in the regime of the shallow or deep seal, it is clearly observed that the cavity expands or shrinks depending on the surface temperature of the sphere. Since the surface temperature at the impact is in the range 105–355 °C and water is at room temperature, the vigorous bubble generation from the phase change would interact with the existing cavity bubble, which results in the increase or decrease in the cavity, being affected by various parameters. Although the absolute value of the maximum cavity size achieved by the laser irradiation is comparable (
V
c
,
m
a
x
/
D
○
3
=
3.2
and 6.0 for
R
○
= 1 mm, and 0.7 and 1.2 for 2 mm sphere, respectively) for shallow- and deep-seal cases, the transition from expansion to shrinkage of the cavity is measured by increasing the surface temperature for the shallow seal, but only the sharp reduction in the cavity is dominant in the case of the deep seal. This indicates that the maximum cavity volume is not affected much by the condition of the cavity, but the destruction of the cavity due to laser irradiation is more closely related to the cavity type.

As the cavity is controlled, the hydrodynamic forces acting on the sphere is affected accordingly. For the shallow-seal case, we have a significant drag reduction (∼45%) whether the cavity becomes larger or smaller owing to the laser irradiation. This is because the complete destruction of the cavity bubble does not occur for the shallow-seal cases, and thus the surface tension force becomes influential. However, for the deep-seal case, the size of the sphere affects a lot. That is, the added mass force is dominant for a smaller sphere and thus the drag reduction is achieved as the surface temperature increases. On the other hand, the buoyancy force becomes more influential for a larger sphere and the drag force becomes larger than the reference case as the surface temperature increases.

In this work, we measured how the cavity bubble behind a sphere in water entry and corresponding forces change over time, which is forced by the highly subcooled boiling triggered by the CW laser irradiation. However, in this kind of highly subcooled water, the cooling process takes place very quickly after the impact. Unfortunately, the facilities and instruments to measure the variation of sphere and water temperatures after the impact are not currently available. On the other hand, previous studies have described the evolution of the cavity shape before the pinch-off using the potential flow theory (
Ducluax
et al.
, 2007
9. Ducluax, V., Caillé, F., Duez, C., Ybert, C., Bocquet, L., and Clanet, C., “
Dynamics of transient cavities
,” J. Fluid Mech.
591
, 1–
19
(2007).
https://doi.org/10.1017/s0022112007007343
;
Aristoff and Bush, 2009
2. Aristoff, J. M. and Bush, J. W. M., “
Water entry of small hydrophobic spheres
,” J. Fluid Mech.
619
, 45–
78
(2009).
https://doi.org/10.1017/s0022112008004382
; and
Truscott
et al.
, 2012
36. Truscott, T. T., Epps, B. P., and Techet, A. H., “
Unsteady forces on spheres during free-surface water entry
,” J. Fluid Mech.
704
, 173–
210
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2012.232
). In the present study, the cavity volume change rate is also dependent on the surface temperature (duration of a focused laser) and furthermore the cavity tends to break into microsized bubbles, which interact with the surrounding liquid. Thus, as a future work, we think it would be very interesting to develop a theoretical framework to estimate the cavity shape considering the contributions of the heated surface and phase change.
